SPAIN
Temp In the time of . Philip 2d. he was very poor yet 58 Archbishops. 684 Bishops. 11 400 abbots. 936 chapters. 127 000 parishes. 7,000 hospitals. 23,000 fraternities. 46,000 monasteries. 135 000 convents. 312 000 secular priests. 200 000 inferior ecclesiastics. 400 000 monks & nuns. & whole population 10.500000. at least 400 000 Moors banished by Philip III.

Philip IIs revenue 30 000 000 of ducats – not half had his Successor, whose public debt exceeded 100. Charles II had only 7 or 8 000 000 of francs. Philip V only 7,500000 souls Charles III had 11 000 000 souls. From beginning of Ferdinands reign to end of next reign revenue had increased from 26,000000 to 60 … … i.e. 60,000,000 of crowns

Conde Vol 2 p108 says el Rey Alfonso de Galicia ufano y evanecido de sus victorias y de la conquista de Toledo cabeza de España y casa principal de los Reyes Godos King Alfonso of Galicia, made proud and conceited [envanecido] by his victories and the conquest of Toledo, capital of Spain and main home of the Gothic Kings having a secret understanding with Abed of Sevilla. Aben Abed Almutamad was king of Seville Alfonso had already made tributary Yahye Alcadir de of Valencia. Alfonso wrote to Aben Abed that he would have certain places & Castles by force.

Alfonso wrote this, "Del Emperador y señor de las dos leyes y naciones, el excelente y poderoso Rey D. Alfonso ben Sancho al Rey Almutemed bila Aben Abed, que Dios fortifique y alumbre su entendimiento para que se determine a seguir el verdadero camino que os conviene. salud y Buena voluntad de parte de un Rey engrandecedor de reynos y amparador de pueblos, al cual han encanecido los cabellos en el conocimiento y prudencia de las cosas y en el ejercicio y destreza de las armas, y en perpetua consecucion de victorias en cuya casa nació la consecution de sus deseos y el cumplimiento de su voluntad en cuyas banderas esta de asiento la Victoria From the Emperor and lord of the two laws and nations, the excellent and powerful King Don Alfonso ben Sancho to King Almutemed bila Aben Abed, may God fortify and illuminate his understanding that he may be determined to follow the true path that suits you [plural]. Health and goodwill on the part of a King who is an aggrandiser of kingdoms and a protector of peoples, whose hair has greyed in the knowledge and prudence of things and in the exercise and skill of arms, and in perpetual achievement of victories, in whose house was born the achievement [Conde has 'consecucion'] of his desires and the fulfilment of his will, in whose banners Victory sits...This is the beginning of a longer letter printed by Conde, vol. 2, pp. 109-10.Conde, Historia de la dominacion, vol. 2, pp. 108-9.

Goths entered Spain 409. beat Romans & natives Goths King married daur of Emp. daughter of Emperor Theodosius. Natives retired to Galicia. 418 Vandals. 456 Theodoric the Goth beat king of Suevi. Euric son of Theodc Theodoric went from Pyrenees to Rhone but Clovis retook this from Alaric son of Euric. 624
Kg King Suintilla
Kg King of whole Peninsula. Ceuta resisted moors. Count Julian its Governor. Musa could not take it. Kg King Witizas Sister Julians wife. 712 Taric defeats Roderic at Xeres. Palagius retires to Asturias. Goths Arians first.

Under Tarik. Royal Legion of Damascus at Cordova. Legion of Emesa at Seville
of Kinnisrin or Calchis at Jaen
of Palestine at Algeziras & Medina Sidonia
of Yemen & Persia at Toledo
Egypt in Murcia & Lisbon
of cavalry of Irak & Syria at Granada. These were 10 000 of the most noble Arabs & Syrians.
Spain under Viceroy of Caliphs till Ommiades Umayyads fell. When one of them came to Spain x was Caliph Abdalrahman. He beat the AbbassidesAbbasids & reigned at Cordova. This race lasted abt 250 years. Then split into Kingdoms.

Pelagius founded Km. Kingdom of Leon. beat Moors 718. 881 Alphonso took Coimbra. Ramirus 2d Madrid & almost Toledo. From David Brewster (ed.), The Edinburgh Encyclopaedia, 18 vols (Edinburgh, 1830), vol. 18, pp. 277-9. The Encyclopaedia paraphrases Edward Gibbon's History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire here (vol. 5, including chapters LI and LII), but the order and precise wording of observations shows WG was reading Brewster.Vide p17 WG's page 17 of this notebook (pag 186).
